WRITING.TITLE: Calling all gaming Youtubers! Is TGN offering to partner with me a scam!?
WRITING.TEXT:
So I recently received a post on my channel from some guy on TGN asking to email about signing up with them. Now I started my YouTube channel on Monday and have 198 subs. One video has 9k views and the other has 1k. (The 9000 one is giving to be featured on Kotaku but I digress). One of my videos is actually a podcast that has a tiny bit about gaming but is mostly about politics. This is the video he left the comment on (why I am skeptical)
Anyway is this guy trying to scam me? If anyone has partnered with TGN can you tell me what it was like?
Thanks!

WRITING.TITLE: MGS6-I think they could make a really interesting game set in the Vietnam War...
WRITING.TEXT:
So I've read the lore of MGS and apparently Big Boss did multiple missions in Vietnam but wasn't this stated on the box art/guide of the original? Which said a number of things that were ret-conned? Anyway doesn't matter.
You could set in in Summer 1968 (think that fits in well between 1964 and Portable ops in 1970) and Snake is convinced by the CIA to rejoin the military in some capacity under his old boss the Major. It could be some sort of mechanised nuclear launch is being tested in Vietnam (or border territories) and Snake has to investigate.
I think they could do something really cool with the open world here. You could have Army bases stand in for 'Mother Base' and maybe carry out certain upgrades. You could drive vehicles from the base and generally interact with the people stationed there. From here you could go out into the world and you could come across civilians, GI's and VC. There could be sporadic battles between the US and NVA/VC that occur when your roaming the countryside.
I think they could show something that really puts Snake at odds with the US military-maybe he's sees an event similar to the My Lai massacre that further cements his distaste for the US. Maybe their could be a brutal group of US soldiers he could go up against?
For characters I'd like to see the return of the MGS3 cast, with EVA making a return especially. I am not sure who the villain but they could delve into Vietnamese mysticism to invent some cool bosses.
What do you guys think? A setting that would suit a new MGS?

WRITING.TITLE: Would Spain have been ethnically cleansed in general?
WRITING.TEXT: So I have been doing 1500's Spain at university. They have their own ethnic cleansing programs in regard to 'converso's', descendants of Jews and Muslims who converted to Christianity. While a final solution was considered for both (and the Moriscos were expelled in 1609) I was generally thinking about the way the rest of Europe view Spain in this period. A lot of them didn't actually consider them to be white. They thought they definitely had Jewish and Muslim 'blood' and that's why they had darker hair and were more coloured than the rest of Europe. Weirdly in a lot of Protestant propaganda they were pretty racist to the Spanish. I know Franco and Hitler were somewhat allied, but does anyone think the Nazi's would ethnically cleanse Spanish people in general? Or would they just accept they were white like people in South America?
AC3 had a bad ending!? Have you played Unity and Syndicate!?

I got a bit more hung up on Platoon as I feel FMJ doesn't really convey the horror of war as well. I liked the characters but they were quite one dimensional. Platoon really made you think how scary and hard it must have been to fight in Vietnam and I like that it conveys the 1 year tour of duty where everyone is counting down the days until they can leave. Both are good but Platoon captures the humanity, or lack of it, in war. FMJ is pretty surreal in comparison I think it's trying to show the madness of war more

WRITING.TITLE: When you see ArsenalFanTv have uploaded a new video after losing 5-1...
Does anyone else find it pretty amazing the US entered World War 1?
WRITING.TEXT: So I've in the past studied 19th century America and Great Britain and if you look about 15 years before the war you would never think the USA would intervene directly in a largely European war. I know the Zimmerman telegram urged Mexico to invade the US and open up a new front but other than this was there any direct threat to the US? Is it true they largely fought to preserve foreign democracies? Was American exceptionalism most prevalent in this war? As on the surface it seems they are doing what they always said/have said since, they are fighting to maintain foreign democracies (literally fight for freedom)-is there any cynical view to their role in the war like there sometimes is with when they joined WW2?

This is a very hard question to answer but in short: guerillas were hard to defeat, will of Hanoi was unbreakable and as it was a totalitarian state it didn't have any pressure on it to stop the war. The revisionist view is that politicians didn't do what was necessary and a lot of US generals belief they weren't allowed to do what was necessary and popular pressure forced them to back off-all of these are debatable.
The South Vietnamese Army didn't perform very well overall throughout the war and its government was extremely corrupt. Many Vietnamese just never wanted to go back to being controlled by another country from China, the French, the Japanese then back to the French then a US backed southern state. It's really complex so you probably have to read a couple book and stuff but hope this points you in the right direction.

WRITING.TITLE: Why do Rebels say to each other 'may the force be with you' ?
WRITING.TEXT: So I was re-watching Rogue One a couple of weeks ago and Jynn said it as they were about to depart for Scariff. Now I can understand this because of her mother believing in the Force. But I'm pretty sure people like Mon Motha and others say it in the original movies. The same Mom Motha who doesn't really know who Obi-Wan is when she speaks to Bail on Yavin 4. Now the Republic didn't explicitly believe in the Force or the Jedi. The Jedi protected the Republic but were shrouded in secrecy-it is probably doubtful a lot of the rebel leaders believed in it before the Empire-so why does the rebellion begin to symbolise believing in the Force and resisting the Empire ? Even if you could say they started when Luke joined them, wouldn't a lot still be skeptics like Han was? Is there any books or something I can check out?

WRITING.TITLE: British casualties in WW2 were way closer to the US than I thought!
WRITING.TEXT:
So just looked up the casualties figures for WW2 by country. I cannot believe the British nearly had the same number of deaths and more injured than the Americans - considering the larger scale of American engagements particularly later in the war- (two beaches on D-Day, Iwo Jima, Peleliu, Okinawa). Am I a noob for not knowing this or is this surprising to anyone else? I know the British lost a lot in 1940 during the Battle of Britain and retreat from France, and they lost a lot in Market Garden but didn't think it was on this scale.
^This Isn't the British Empire it's just for the UK.

Yeah I totally see your point and you make a good argument about the way the American tanks were easier to make and maintain. My point really was that the Nazi's created stuff that was ahead of heir time and the best in certain respects - but this didn't translate to success on the battlefield

This is the best answer I've seen so thanks a lot ! Some of the stuff you said I did know (probably should have included) - I knew the Americans were generally the most advanced but I was citing the examples I believe the Nazi's were more advanced although this isn't to say I think their inventions made a difference. My point with things like the V2 were that they were the first to make a working rocket/ground based missile regardless if it was effective or not
